 Agence France-Presse, by Staff 
 From correspondents in Rotterdam
 
 
 May 03, 2005
 
 Rotterdam - Mohammed Bouyeri, the man accused of the murder of filmmaker Theo van Gogh, played ''a leading role'' in an Islamic terrorist organisation dubbed the Hofstad group, a prosecutor said in a procedural hearing on the group on Tuesday. /break/ ''Bouyeri took literature from the Internet which preached and glorified the use of violence. He himself wrote articles in which he advocated the use of deadly violence.''
 
 (Snip)
 
 The 12, all young Muslims mainly of North-African descent, were arrested in November and December last year after the brutal murder of Van Gogh in an Amsterdam street.
 
 Police say the alleged killer, Mr Bouyeri, acted out of radical Islamic beliefs. A letter found pinned to Van Gogh's body contained quotations from the Koran and threats to liberal lawmaker Ayaan Hirsi Ali, known for her criticism of Islam...
